headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation's Q1 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Phipps, Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation. Thank you. Mr. Phipps, you
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation's Q1 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Phipps, Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation. Thank you. Mr. Phipps, you may begin.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Claudia. Well, good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2010 results. Joining me today are all the members of our executive committee, as well as other member of senior management. While we wil
componenttext:
Thank you, Claudia. Well, good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2010 results. Joining me today are all the members of our executive committee, as well as other member of senior management. While we will not be referencing slides during the call, we did file a deck earlier with the SEC, and I encourage you to have these available as we progress through this morning's call.
These slides, along with other financial results, including the press release and supplemental quarterly data, can be found on our website at tsocorp.com. After reviewing this information, please feel free to contact me for any questions about this material or otherwise, following today's call. Please refer to the forward-looking statements in the earnings slide, which says that statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and/or future predictions, are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Act, as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations. I'll now provide second quarter 2010 guidance for modeling purposes.
In these assumptions, we had assumed the Anacortes refinery is fully shut down as of the end of this month, and will remain so for the duration of the quarter. We have used this purely for assumption purposes, and currently have no estimated time for a restart. We estimate throughput to be 75,000 to 85,000 barrels per day in the Pacific Northwest region; 70,000 to 80,000 barrels per day in the Mid-Pacific; 85,000 to 95,000 barrels a day in Mid-Continent, as a result of the Mandan turnaround; and 240,000  to 250,000 barrels per day in the California region, which is higher than a quarter ago, due to the Golden Eagle maintenance during February.
OpEx guidance for the second quarter is as follows: $6.50 per barrel in the Pacific Northwest region. The higher per barrel number is primarily a reflection of the lower throughput; $3 per barrel in the Mid-Pacific; $4.20 per barrel in the Mid-Continent; and $6.85 per barrel in the California region, which is lower than last quarter, primarily due to higher throughput.
Our depreciation for refining is estimated at $75 million. This amount is lower than our historical average, as we have extended the useful life of certain process units since our previous turnaround. Additional second quarter guidance items include corporate expense of $45 million, and interest expense before interest income of $35 million.
I'll now turn the call over to Bruce.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everybody, and thanks for joining us for today's call. Before we discuss the press release, I want to express my deepest sympathy to all those individuals, who have been affected by the tragic accident that occurred a
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everybody, and thanks for joining us for today's call. Before we discuss the press release, I want to express my deepest sympathy to all those individuals, who have been affected by the tragic accident that occurred at Anacortes. The entire Tesoro family is deeply saddened by the loss of seven co-workers, and we're generally concerned about their families and friends. And our thoughts and prayers are with all our employees and their love ones.
No one's ever adequately prepared to manage a crisis like this one. But I'm extremely proud of the way the management team and a very broad group of employees have dealt with the myriad issues created by this unfortunate incident. Don Sorensen, the manager in Anacortes, and his team have done an excellent job of compassionately meeting the needs of our employees, the affected families. And at the same time, they've done an exemplary job of cooperating with and providing information and assistance to the various investigation teams. We will continue to make every effort to assist those who are trying to determine the cause of the incident, and to provide support and help to the affected parties.
It's a little difficult to shift gears after those comments. But on today's agenda, I want to briefly review our first quarter results, update you on our non-capital improvement initiatives and provide some color on what we currently see in the West Coast market.
As we reported yesterday, in the first quarter, the company reported a net loss of $155 million or $1.11 per share. These results include an after-tax impairment charge of $12 million associated with the deferral of a capital project at the Los Angeles refinery, a $7 million tax charge related to the recent Congressional healthcare legislation and $7 million in after-tax accruals for our employee incentive compensation program, which is a change from our previous accounting practice.
The compensation committee has decided to make a quarterly accrual of targeted amount, and then make appropriate adjustments based on performance. This adjustment is included in the guidance numbers that Scott just provided. 
The first quarter segment operating loss of $145 million is attributable to a Tesoro index, which was half of what we saw a year ago. The positives in the first quarter are that we captured 10% more of the available margin compared to the first quarter of last year. And even though first quarter margins were much lower than we anticipated, we continue to manage our operations and capital program to conserve cash, just as we've done since late 2007.
Since excess capacity among U.S. refineries has limited margin expansion, our entire organization is focused on financial and operational excellence. Our priorities are to maximize cash, optimize the system at these low margins, and to execute the non-capital initiative program.
For years, we have been optimizing system feedstock selection by acquiring new and/or economically advantaged crudes relative to available alternatives. During the first quarter, we ran two new crudes in our system in a period of single-digit indices, a meaningful discount in our feedstock cost helped us achieve the additional margin capture that I mentioned earlier.
We've made adjustments to the operating system as a result of the shutdown of Anacortes. I know you have many questions about the incident, but we really don't have any new information to provide. The cause is still unknown. And due to the ongoing nature of the investigations at the refinery, I can only provide a few facts. 
Operationally, we announced our intention to halt crude runs. And as of yesterday afternoon, all the refinery process units were safely shut down. Since the fire, Anacortes have been producing primarily unfinished product that couldn't be upgraded in Anacortes, so we've been moving that product to other plants within our system. We've diverted the crude cargoes that were scheduled to arrive at Anacortes to other refineries. In order to minimize potential product supply disruptions to the extent necessary, we have been supplying our transportation fuel customers with product from third parties.
To date, we have not made any significant adjustments to our capital program, nor do we know what the post financial impact might be. We believe we have adequate insurance coverage, including property and business interruption insurance. Our business interruption deductible is 60 days, and then a loss of $25 million, primarily related to the operating plan that existed prior to the incident. And the property deductible is $10 million. I will repeat that in light of the investigations, which is still taking place, we're not going to speculate about any matter associated with this event, and we will not take speculative questions about it.
From a capital spending perspective, the highly disciplined review process that we initiated several years ago, continues to have very positive cash benefits. Today, our capital spending is considerably lower than it was projected to be three months ago. Why? Because the objective of this process is to identify the most efficient use of capital in all aspects of project management, including optimum designs, scheduling cost management, without compromising our two fundamentals: safety and reliability. 
The capital management process involves structured reviews at multiple key points in the development of each project to ensure all possible alternatives are considered; standards of safety, reliability and regulations are met; the expenditures are timed to meet requirements; and the most effective cost materials and labor are used.
The result is that, in many case, that the early estimates of project cost are reduced, and our actual cost can be below projections. As noted in the press release yesterday, our first quarter capital spending of $99 million, which includes turnarounds, came in below guidance, as this review process resulted in a lower turnaround spending at Golden Eagle and project spending at Salt Lake City.
When we reported our 2009 results in February, we revised our full year 2010 capital program estimate down from $675 million to $600 million. Including our first quarter progress and continued efforts this year, we now expect the 2010 capital program to be in the $500 million to $525 million range.
The $75 million to $100 million decline is another example of the success of this process. A specific example, we expected to spend almost $50 million for the remainder of the year on a number of projects in L.A., but we found ways to reduce that spending. And then, as I said at the start of today's call, we also took a $12 million impairment charge related to a multi-year deferral of a group of regulatory projects at L.A. that totaled around $350 million.
Also mentioned that effective cash management involves not only our capital review, but it also focuses on our operating plans to improve our capture rate. In The first quarter, we realized $27 million from non-capital initiatives, despite the difficulties created by the extremely low margin environment in January and early February.
To highlight some of these benefits, we optimized our marine fleet by out-chartering excess ship capacity to other parties. Additionally, in our marketing channels, we made some changes that delivered benefits in both margins and costs, a trend that we expect will be sustainable going forward.
And within our refining and optimization groups, we saw improvements in yield and inventory execution. In many cases, capturing the full value of these non-capital initiatives requires teamwork within a department, as well as cross-functional coordination. 
Turning to the second quarter, we started to see improvement at the differentials for California heavy crudes, which historically lag foreign heavy crude differentials. While the domestic differentials didn't materialize until late in the first quarter, we do expect to see the benefit during the second quarter. On the product side, I would say, in broad terms, we are seeing demand stability for light products. But clearly, gasoline supply is above last year's inventory level, and also the five-year range.
We believe, like many of you who write about the industry, that unemployment right now is the largest factor in preventing a return to growing gasoline demand. While the increase in unemployment in California has declined, and it appears to be stable, we need to see a sharp decline in that statistic before we expect to see demand growth. Accordingly, I do not believe we will change the corporate philosophy I outlined in our last earnings call. We will continue to manage and focus business execution around safety, reliability and cash conservation. To achieve this, we need to be diligent, flexible and sensitive to changes in the marketplace.
We must deliver on system non-capital initiatives, which we still expect to be in line with our original guidance of $160 million to $170 million. And finally, even though we've reduced our 2010 capital program, we expect to spend approximately $60 million of income improvement, those quick hit projects we've talked about. So we expect to spend $60 million this year.
We expect these small high-return projects located across our entire asset base to improve cash flow and generate real return for our shareholders, particularly since those returns are a little more resilient to margins.
Before I open the call to questions, I want to thank everyone for their support, for their interest and for the great analytical work that you've given to me during my almost 18 years of service here at Tesoro. In any corporation, there are highs and there have certainly been some lows. But nevertheless, it's been a real privilege and honor to be in this position for so many years. I want to thank my management team, and I want to acknowledge the excellent commitment that they've shown to our shareholders. I know Greg Goff and the management team will continue to do an excellent job for our shareholders, and that I'm very confident that you'll enjoy working with and getting to know Greg. 
Finally, just one last thing, in a not too distant future, the other Greg, Greg Wright, is also going to join me in retirement. And I want to take this opportunity, since he won't be participating in future calls, to thank him for his tireless support and wise counsel for so many years. I know that many of you have known Greg for a long time, and I wanted you to have the opportunity to say goodbye. And Greg, would you like to say anything before we take questions?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would, Bruce, thank you. Bruce is correct, and that I will soon be concluding my 15-year career at Tesoro. And if I count it right, some 38 years in the energy industry. I've been humbled by the support I've received during my tenure as CFO. And if you
componenttext:
I would, Bruce, thank you. Bruce is correct, and that I will soon be concluding my 15-year career at Tesoro. And if I count it right, some 38 years in the energy industry. I've been humbled by the support I've received during my tenure as CFO. And if you look at just the Investor Relations area, I began doing Investor Relations back in the dark ages, 1983. And it's been a part of my responsibility, virtually, every year since then. And I'll miss the relationships I have with many of you, and I wish you the very best going forward.
I'm appreciative of the tremendously talented management team and the hard-working employees with whom I've worked. We have accomplished some great things together during some difficult times, and I'll miss the challenge. But I know the new management team will be up to meeting it. Thank you, all, for your support.

componenttext: I think, since we don't have approval yet, it's hard to say that we'd a benefit. I mean, we don't have any baked in our plan really. And so I think once we know where we are and we'll review it with the board, we can talk a little bit more about it. But it's certainly probably more likely to be a third quarter event from a modeling perspective. And I'd say, like most things, I mean, there's going to be a little bit of trial and error in what we're doing here. I mean, I think even with the plan that we're looking at, it'll take us a little bit of time to really fully realize the value of that. We'll see. But I mean, I would expect it would be more of a growing process.

componenttext: The Russian crude is producing at about 350,000 barrels per day. The discounts, we take advantage of being one of the first ones to purchase the crude and getting substantial discounts. The good thing about the ESPO is that it's putting pressure on the Alaskan North Slope crude, which we also buy, and providing us a benefit in that manner.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little early. I mean, the production level is supposed to grow, and it may have broader implications all the way around. It's a little early. I was asking a question today about this crude as we were talking, and this is a continuation of a program
componenttext: It's a little early. I mean, the production level is supposed to grow, and it may have broader implications all the way around. It's a little early. I was asking a question today about this crude as we were talking, and this is a continuation of a program that we've had now that's five, six years old, of buying these ordinary crudes, being the first buyer. I was told that we processed 100 new crudes or around 100 new crudes. So again, this is one that potentially has some more positive benefits for us because it does maybe put some pressure on more broadly that quality crude in the Pacific area.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just in the press release, you alluded too that you're seeing some improvement in gasoline demand since the start of the year. Could you just provide a little bit more color not only from the start of the year but sort of year-over-year? And then, the tre
componenttext: Just in the press release, you alluded too that you're seeing some improvement in gasoline demand since the start of the year. Could you just provide a little bit more color not only from the start of the year but sort of year-over-year? And then, the trends that you're seeing in light of the addition of the increase in ethanol into the California gasoline?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lynn Westfall will be glad to help you with that.
componenttext: Lynn Westfall will be glad to help you with that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, the numbers we got yesterday for February were encouraging. We've had five gasoline showing a year-over-year increase of about 6.6%. January was at 3.2%. So it's moving in the right direction. The issue though is that, that was building o
componenttext: Well, certainly, the numbers we got yesterday for February were encouraging. We've had five gasoline showing a year-over-year increase of about 6.6%. January was at 3.2%. So it's moving in the right direction. The issue though is that, that was building on a very low 2008 numbers, where gasoline was down almost 11%. So the direction is good on gasoline demand, but it's building off of a very low base. Certainly, we're expecting to see what we normally see at this time of the year, which is seasonality in gasoline demand. Typically, second quarter versus first quarter, demand goes up in the neighborhood of 50,000 to 60,000 barrels a day. I think it's fair to say that we're cautiously optimistic about demand. But as long as unemployment stays as high as it is, and I think that's going to be with us for probably most of the rest of this year, we would expect to see significant demand increases. But at least now, we have the direction going right or maybe stable. So I think that's kind of our view on gasoline demand going forward. On your second question, CARB gasoline, we've got four months worth of data right now, but the interpretation of that data can vary. What the data says for four months out of this year, for California refinery, is that CARB gasoline yield, which includes downstream ethanol blending is exactly equal to what it was last year. But overall gasoline yield is up about 3.5%. So right now, it appears from the data, the excess is actually showing up in conventional gasoline. That's the data, and now the interpretation can vary. Interpretations can be that it was caused by turnarounds that are forcing people to be make conventional than CARB. It can be that demand is only being met by CARB gasoline yield, and excess is into conventional. So the economics maybe forcing people to make more conventional in CARB. So overall, gasoline yield, as I said, is up. It's not as up as much as you would expect from the conversion from 5.7% to 10%. It's only up, as I said, about 3.5% versus about 4.5% you'd expect from the ethanol yield. So the data's still young, and we'll look at it, as we go forward, maybe able to get some better conclusions.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following that up, how about what you're seeing on the distillate side, diesel particularly, in terms of demand?
componenttext: Just following that up, how about what you're seeing on the distillate side, diesel particularly, in terms of demand?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the local demand, certainly, isn't what we'd hoped for. But it's getting same picture as gasoline. We saw January go up 2.1%. February is down 1%. I think the major story on diesel demand is local demand, it's export. We've seen, I think, some prett
componenttext: Well, the local demand, certainly, isn't what we'd hoped for. But it's getting same picture as gasoline. We saw January go up 2.1%. February is down 1%. I think the major story on diesel demand is local demand, it's export. We've seen, I think, some pretty good export activity out of the West Coast on distillate in March and continued on in April, primarily going down to South America. So again, I think that's really going to be the picture for distillate demand going forward for the next several months.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, if I could just jump back on one of the things you highlighted, ESPO crude. We've been watching this pretty carefully. And I guess the question we want to ask is, have they been aggressively pricing these crudes in order to get things going?
componenttext: First of all, if I could just jump back on one of the things you highlighted, ESPO crude. We've been watching this pretty carefully. And I guess the question we want to ask is, have they been aggressively pricing these crudes in order to get things going? Or do you think the dynamics that we've seen here are relatively sustainable? And I guess, just as a kind of related question. If I look at the widening of ANS, well, obviously, we're coming into maintenance in Alaska here, I guess, pretty soon. Do you think that kind of dynamic or that kind of discount, again, is something we might see as a more sustainable basis? I believe, ESPO crude are looking at something like trebling the production over the next couple of years. So obviously, we're pretty interested to know how this plays to your market.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, this is Chuck Flagg. I think, initially, we got a very good discount on ESPO as refiners become more aware of the crude, particularly in the Far East. It's putting pressure both on far eastern crudes, and as I said earlier, on the ANS. The ANS
componenttext: Yes, Doug, this is Chuck Flagg. I think, initially, we got a very good discount on ESPO as refiners become more aware of the crude, particularly in the Far East. It's putting pressure both on far eastern crudes, and as I said earlier, on the ANS. The ANS has blown out. As you indicated, we are coming in to the summer maintenance season in Alaska. So we would expect at least directional tightening on the ANS. But again, the ESPO is coming into the West Coast, and I believe it will continue to pressure the Alaskan crude.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: The final one for me is just on the CapEx deferrals. I guess, Bruce, in your prepared remarks, you talked about multi-year deferral of regulatory CapEx. Can you just talk about how you've been able to achieve that and maybe a little more granularity as to
componenttext: The final one for me is just on the CapEx deferrals. I guess, Bruce, in your prepared remarks, you talked about multi-year deferral of regulatory CapEx. Can you just talk about how you've been able to achieve that and maybe a little more granularity as to whether that capital is just going to shift into next year? Or if these are actual permanent reductions for capital spending?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think they're going to be permanent, but they're not going to be in the near years. They've really been -- this effort, that's been going on just as I said in my prepared remarks. In order to develop a budget, much of these works done on such a pr
componenttext: I don't think they're going to be permanent, but they're not going to be in the near years. They've really been -- this effort, that's been going on just as I said in my prepared remarks. In order to develop a budget, much of these works done on such a preliminary basis. And with the dynamic processes that are in the market and the way we're looking at rescheduling and better procurement, we've found some ways with some permanent  NOx credits to do some things that we didn't anticipate. So it really is -- it's a lot of solutions that come together but at the end, you're probably going to have spend some dollars. Eric,  do you want to comment on or...

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me expound on that a little bit. We had a project. It was quite a large project for  NOx control  in Los Angeles, and it involved a number of pieces that were relatively low return energy savings around cogeneration and boiler replacements. When we de
componenttext: Let me expound on that a little bit. We had a project. It was quite a large project for  NOx control  in Los Angeles, and it involved a number of pieces that were relatively low return energy savings around cogeneration and boiler replacements. When we deconstructed that project in this environment with the lower energy costs and a more constrained capital, we found a combination of commercial and more efficient investments to achieve the necessary  NOx control. So we got the  NOx control  done with a combination of perpetual  NOx credits that we bought in the market at a good price and a much less reduced capital investment. At some point in the future, but I think outside, our current planning horizon, we'll still go back and look at those boiler and cogeneration projects. But I wouldn't be concerned about them in the current planning horizon.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the key is really through this low margin cycle, where we think they -- for whether it's one or two or three years. We've done some things to permanently change what we're going to do to be able to generate free cash flow.
componenttext: I think the key is really through this low margin cycle, where we think they -- for whether it's one or two or three years. We've done some things to permanently change what we're going to do to be able to generate free cash flow.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: This is actually Sean Kelly  on behalf of Ed, he's tied up on another call. I wanted to chat a little bit about demand. You guys have done a good job answering -- my question actually, on your website, you have unemployment data and other gasoline and diesel demand data. I was wondering if you're seeing anything in the ports, anything on the ground that's kind of an indicator to what's going on with the distillate  demand?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Lynn Westfall. At this point in time, I think it's the same picture as we're seeing with gasoline demand. It looks stable but not rising. As far as the leapings  at the port, they're going up from where they were. They're certainly not to the leve
componenttext: This is Lynn Westfall. At this point in time, I think it's the same picture as we're seeing with gasoline demand. It looks stable but not rising. As far as the leapings  at the port, they're going up from where they were. They're certainly not to the level they used to be. The driver for distillate demand that is coming up on us shortly will be the planning season. So I think that's good. As far as internal demand to the West Coast, I'm not talking about export demand, I think that will be the primary factor that we'll be looking at in the second quarter.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: And building back on the CapEx or the capital program. I was actually at your Analyst Day in New York in the fall. With regards to your kind of out to 2013 guidance, the question was kind of answered previously, but what are you looking at in terms of the
componenttext: And building back on the CapEx or the capital program. I was actually at your Analyst Day in New York in the fall. With regards to your kind of out to 2013 guidance, the question was kind of answered previously, but what are you looking at in terms of the total spend out in 2012 and 2013?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Frank can kind of chime in as well. But we are -- if the question is kind of where we're pushing out of this year, we're going to see it in the next two years. I don't think we see that kind of a trend. I think our outlooks are still pretty consistent
componenttext: And Frank can kind of chime in as well. But we are -- if the question is kind of where we're pushing out of this year, we're going to see it in the next two years. I don't think we see that kind of a trend. I think our outlooks are still pretty consistent in the outer years from what you saw on the previous plans.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would agree. There's certainly nothing beyond the quick capital program that we've got that we may find other ways of adding to that, but it's going to be small. And probably, directionally things are still down as we've find this process being much mor
componenttext: I would agree. There's certainly nothing beyond the quick capital program that we've got that we may find other ways of adding to that, but it's going to be small. And probably, directionally things are still down as we've find this process being much more successful than maybe we expect it to be. A lot of those projects just maybe haven't seen where we're going to be in the review. And of course, procurements will be different. So that direction, it will probably be still down.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Have you given any other guidance with respect to Hawaii and how do you continue to view that refinery?
componenttext: Have you given any other guidance with respect to Hawaii and how do you continue to view that refinery?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't given any other guidance on Hawaii. I think that in one of the comments that I made, we continue -- we've been very active in looking at all of our assets, and it goes to really the capital and the operations and in that particular instance, so
componenttext: We haven't given any other guidance on Hawaii. I think that in one of the comments that I made, we continue -- we've been very active in looking at all of our assets, and it goes to really the capital and the operations and in that particular instance, some of the ways that we market product. I think they were making progress in across all those fronts with our customers. And I do think that with regard to why that we're closer to being able to potentially unlock some additional value there. So I think that Hawaii is still a focus for us. A lot of efforts going into determining how we can improve the profitability of that on a sustainable basis. And I think it's sort of multi-functional, and I think we'll end up being successful in coming back to describe some of the things we've been able to do.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: On product demand, it's really on the flip side of Chi's question. Latin demand for incremental product has also been positive due to refining outages and lower hydro levels. I was wondering if you could discuss that arbitrage or how to sort of maybe benefiting or any thoughts really heading into Latin American winter here?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Evan, Chuck Flagg. We have seen a tremendous demand pull particularly coming from Chile and Mexico in particular, where there's some refinery downtime. We've been putting cargoes together and shipping it down there as have our competitors. So it's really
componenttext: Evan, Chuck Flagg. We have seen a tremendous demand pull particularly coming from Chile and Mexico in particular, where there's some refinery downtime. We've been putting cargoes together and shipping it down there as have our competitors. So it's really putting an incremental demand on the West Coast, which I think is contributing to our higher margins that we've seen thus far.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about on the flip side? If you heading east. I mean, with lower utilization, can you increase runs, secure delivery through Calnev or maybe how do you think about Calnev versus the proposed UNEV  since you're on both sides of that market?
componenttext: How about on the flip side? If you heading east. I mean, with lower utilization, can you increase runs, secure delivery through Calnev or maybe how do you think about Calnev versus the proposed UNEV  since you're on both sides of that market?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the demand in Las Vegas, well it had been growing, has certainly slowed. UNEV, as it now stands, we have not committed any barrels to it. And so it remains to be seen as far as how many barrels actually are committed to UNEV.
componenttext: Well, the demand in Las Vegas, well it had been growing, has certainly slowed. UNEV, as it now stands, we have not committed any barrels to it. And so it remains to be seen as far as how many barrels actually are committed to UNEV.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what about now in terms of going through Calnev?
componenttext: And what about now in terms of going through Calnev?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't put a whole lot of barrels into Calnev ourselves. That line is currently full. So at the margin, barrels tend to get trapped. But again, demand is very much down in Las Vegas. It's one of the most impacted areas in the country.
componenttext: We don't put a whole lot of barrels into Calnev ourselves. That line is currently full. So at the margin, barrels tend to get trapped. But again, demand is very much down in Las Vegas. It's one of the most impacted areas in the country.

componenttext: It's really the incentive compensation accrual. It's a change of that method. That's a principle. There's a little bit of stock-based compensation, but it's partially driven that change in compensation method. And then we also have Bill  Finnerty, you may remember left the corporation. And so we took a charge relative to that. So really sort of three sort of big baskets there. The incentive compensation was about $3 million, and so that will continue and that's build into the guidance that Scott gave you.

componenttext: Bruce, on the latest cut in the CapEx from the 600 to 500 to 525, is there any particular project that you can share, say, what that maybe?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Everett. The latest cut really isn't in any one big project. It's probably scattered over 15 to 20 smaller projects. And it's part of that process that we go through, where we look very carefully at each project and make sure we haven't got any ex
componenttext: This is Everett. The latest cut really isn't in any one big project. It's probably scattered over 15 to 20 smaller projects. And it's part of that process that we go through, where we look very carefully at each project and make sure we haven't got any excess capital going into that program. So there isn't a single big project now. It's scattered over a range of projects.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: I have no reason to believe that DD&A expense wont be. I don't know that for a fact. But we have -- on overall forecast, we are building that way. componenttext: This is Everett. For your modeling purposes, what you're using now in terms of cash fixed operating expense will be similar and maybe slightly lower. headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: I need to think about that. I'm a little reluctant to start isolating expenses here because we've got two refineries that are combined in there. And for competitive reasons, I'm not sure we're going to break that out. I need to think about that. I'll think five minutes before I retire this afternoon. But I'm not sure about that information if for that reason because one of things I don't want to do is start doing too much around that, that starts to give competitive information relative to what the other refinery might be. So I'm a little sensitive to that. I've talked to the team here about that even in the second quarter. So just please give us a little time to think about that, and we'll let you know where we come out.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Gilman with Benchmark.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Gilman with Benchmark.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: It's Eli Bauman on behalf of Mark, actually. I was wondering how much flexibility you have to defer LA-related regulatory projects?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Everett, I can't answer that question.
componenttext: Everett, I can't answer that question.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's awfully perspective. We, of course, are going to stay in compliance with all the regulatory requirements around Los Angeles, and that's the first driver. And the best guidance we have today is what you've got in our forward plans, and I would use t
componenttext: That's awfully perspective. We, of course, are going to stay in compliance with all the regulatory requirements around Los Angeles, and that's the first driver. And the best guidance we have today is what you've got in our forward plans, and I would use that. But I think in the back of your minds, as we continue to look at that process, we tend to find ways to reduce it, but we can't say that at this point.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: You look at the first quarter, and just when we were looking at that in the fourth quarter, I mean, we made a significant reduction in the first quarter this year. I think that what I said earlier about when you look at the out years and we look at capita
componenttext: You look at the first quarter, and just when we were looking at that in the fourth quarter, I mean, we made a significant reduction in the first quarter this year. I think that what I said earlier about when you look at the out years and we look at capital, and you look at this low margin environment, we set a new standard for ourselves, and this will be even when margins improved. But the process we've got going on we believe will continue to find ways to reduce the capital investment. And particularly, capital investments associated as with its non-productive regulatory capital. The safety, the reliability, we just have the fundamental. There's not one meeting that Everett and I go to that we don't talk about we're not going to compromise that. So it's all about finding other ways to save money, and I just think it's part of what we're going to do and you're going to continue to see revisions that go down. If all of a sudden, the economy is so robust, you might see changes going up because the materials and labor get more expensive than where we planned, but that's not the environment we're in.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: Our last question is coming from the line of Jacques Rousseau with RBC.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: The balance sheet looks in good shape with a debt to cap of 39%. I just wanted to see if you could give a status of the tangible network covenant. If my math was correct, there was about a $300 million push at the end of the year?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to thank everybody again. I appreciate all the very, very great -- I both appreciate the kind comments that so many people made. I think the many wishes for a good retirement, the only person that may not be happy about that is my wife, Gail, who h
componenttext: I want to thank everybody again. I appreciate all the very, very great -- I both appreciate the kind comments that so many people made. I think the many wishes for a good retirement, the only person that may not be happy about that is my wife, Gail, who has already told me that I need to find something else to do. But I want to tell you all, once again, that it's truly been a pleasure. I know that the second quarter conference call will be a little bit more unusual, having done this for a long time. But I actually think that we're on the verge of starting to see some very positive changes in the marketplace. As we've talked, just if you look at everything statistically, a 12-month comparison is like day and night anymore. I mean the world was so different 12 months ago, just as we look at all statistics and as people look about coming out of the recession and the statistics still don't show that we're coming out of recession. I think that we are positioned, and I think that the continued focus on cash and being able to employ cash more effectively for shareholders is going to continue, and it's going to continue -- it's going to start to show some real benefits here in the last half of the year. So once again, thank you very much. And I'll be on your end of the phone listening to the second quarter. Operator, that's it.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation's Q1 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Phipps, Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation. Thank you. Mr. Phipps, you
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation's Q1 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Scott Phipps, Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation. Thank you. Mr. Phipps, you may begin.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Claudia. Well, good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2010 results. Joining me today are all the members of our executive committee, as well as other member of senior management. While we wil
componenttext:
Thank you, Claudia. Well, good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our first quarter 2010 results. Joining me today are all the members of our executive committee, as well as other member of senior management. While we will not be referencing slides during the call, we did file a deck earlier with the SEC, and I encourage you to have these available as we progress through this morning's call.
These slides, along with other financial results, including the press release and supplemental quarterly data, can be found on our website at tsocorp.com. After reviewing this information, please feel free to contact me for any questions about this material or otherwise, following today's call. Please refer to the forward-looking statements in the earnings slide, which says that statements made during this call that refer to management's expectations and/or future predictions, are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Act, as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations. I'll now provide second quarter 2010 guidance for modeling purposes.
In these assumptions, we had assumed the Anacortes refinery is fully shut down as of the end of this month, and will remain so for the duration of the quarter. We have used this purely for assumption purposes, and currently have no estimated time for a restart. We estimate throughput to be 75,000 to 85,000 barrels per day in the Pacific Northwest region; 70,000 to 80,000 barrels per day in the Mid-Pacific; 85,000 to 95,000 barrels a day in Mid-Continent, as a result of the Mandan turnaround; and 240,000  to 250,000 barrels per day in the California region, which is higher than a quarter ago, due to the Golden Eagle maintenance during February.
OpEx guidance for the second quarter is as follows: $6.50 per barrel in the Pacific Northwest region. The higher per barrel number is primarily a reflection of the lower throughput; $3 per barrel in the Mid-Pacific; $4.20 per barrel in the Mid-Continent; and $6.85 per barrel in the California region, which is lower than last quarter, primarily due to higher throughput.
Our depreciation for refining is estimated at $75 million. This amount is lower than our historical average, as we have extended the useful life of certain process units since our previous turnaround. Additional second quarter guidance items include corporate expense of $45 million, and interest expense before interest income of $35 million.
I'll now turn the call over to Bruce.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everybody, and thanks for joining us for today's call. Before we discuss the press release, I want to express my deepest sympathy to all those individuals, who have been affected by the tragic accident that occurred a
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everybody, and thanks for joining us for today's call. Before we discuss the press release, I want to express my deepest sympathy to all those individuals, who have been affected by the tragic accident that occurred at Anacortes. The entire Tesoro family is deeply saddened by the loss of seven co-workers, and we're generally concerned about their families and friends. And our thoughts and prayers are with all our employees and their love ones.
No one's ever adequately prepared to manage a crisis like this one. But I'm extremely proud of the way the management team and a very broad group of employees have dealt with the myriad issues created by this unfortunate incident. Don Sorensen, the manager in Anacortes, and his team have done an excellent job of compassionately meeting the needs of our employees, the affected families. And at the same time, they've done an exemplary job of cooperating with and providing information and assistance to the various investigation teams. We will continue to make every effort to assist those who are trying to determine the cause of the incident, and to provide support and help to the affected parties.
It's a little difficult to shift gears after those comments. But on today's agenda, I want to briefly review our first quarter results, update you on our non-capital improvement initiatives and provide some color on what we currently see in the West Coast market.
As we reported yesterday, in the first quarter, the company reported a net loss of $155 million or $1.11 per share. These results include an after-tax impairment charge of $12 million associated with the deferral of a capital project at the Los Angeles refinery, a $7 million tax charge related to the recent congressional healthcare legislation and $7 million in after-tax accruals for our employee incentive compensation program, which is a change from our previous accounting practice.
The compensation committee has decided to make a quarterly accrual of a targeted amount, and then make appropriate adjustments based on performance. This adjustment is included in the guidance numbers that Scott just provided. 
The first quarter segment operating loss of $145 million is attributable to a Tesoro index, which was half of what we saw a year ago. The positives in the first quarter are that we captured 10% more of the available margin compared to the first quarter of last year. And even though first quarter margins were much lower than we anticipated, we continue to manage our operations and capital program to conserve cash, just as we've done since late 2007.
Since excess capacity among U.S. refineries has limited margin expansion, our entire organization is focused on financial and operational excellence. Our priorities are to maximize cash, optimize the system at these low margins, and to execute the non-capital initiative program.
For years, we have been optimizing system feedstock selection by acquiring new and/or economically advantaged crudes relative to available alternatives. During the first quarter, we ran two new crudes in our system in a period of single-digit indices, a meaningful discount in our feedstock cost helped us achieve the additional margin capture that I mentioned earlier.
We've made adjustments to the operating system as a result of the shutdown of Anacortes. I know you have many questions about the incident, but we really don't have any new information to provide. The cause is still unknown. And due to the ongoing nature of the investigations at the refinery, I can only provide a few facts. 
Operationally, we announced our intention to halt crude runs. And as of yesterday afternoon, all the refinery process units were safely shut down. Since the fire, Anacortes have been producing primarily unfinished product that couldn't be upgraded in Anacortes, so we've been moving that product to other plants within our system. We've diverted the crude cargoes that were scheduled to arrive at Anacortes to other refineries. In order to minimize potential product supply disruptions to the extent necessary, we have been supplying our transportation fuel customers with product from third parties.
To date, we have not made any significant adjustments to our capital program, nor do we know what the post financial impact might be. We believe we have adequate insurance coverage, including property and business interruption insurance. Our business interruption deductible is 60 days, and then a loss of $25 million, primarily related to the operating plan that existed prior to the incident. And the property deductible is $10 million. I will repeat that in light of the investigations, which is still taking place, we're not going to speculate about any matter associated with this event, and we will not take speculative questions about it.
From a capital spending perspective, the highly disciplined review process that we initiated several years ago continues to have very positive cash benefits. Today, our capital spending is considerably lower than it was projected to be three months ago. Why? Because the objective of this process is to identify the most efficient use of capital in all aspects of project management, including optimum designs, scheduling cost management, without compromising our two fundamentals: safety and reliability. 
The capital management process involves structured reviews at multiple key points in the development of each project to ensure all possible alternatives are considered; standards of safety, reliability and regulations are met; the expenditures are timed to meet requirements; and the most effective cost materials and labor are used.
The result is that, in many cases, the early estimates of project costs are reduced, and our actual cost can be below projections. As noted in the press release yesterday, our first quarter capital spending of $99 million, which includes turnarounds, came in below guidance, as this review process resulted in a lower turnaround spending at Golden Eagle and project spending at Salt Lake City.
When we reported our 2009 results in February, we revised our full year 2010 capital program estimate down from $675 million to $600 million. Including our first quarter progress and continued efforts this year, we now expect the 2010 capital program to be in the $500 million to $525 million range.
The $75 million to $100 million decline is another example of the success of this process. A specific example, we expected to spend almost $50 million for the remainder of the year on a number of projects in L.A., but we found ways to reduce that spending. And then, as I said at the start of today's call, we also took a $12 million impairment charge related to a multi-year deferral of a group of regulatory projects at L.A. that totaled around $350 million.
I Also mentioned that effective cash management involves not only our capital review, but it also focuses on our operating plans to improve our capture rate. In The first quarter, we realized $27 million from non-capital initiatives, despite the difficulties created by the extremely low margin environment in January and early February.
To highlight some of these benefits, we optimized our marine fleet by out-chartering excess ship capacity to other parties. Additionally, in our marketing channels, we made some changes that delivered benefits in both margins and costs, a trend that we expect will be sustainable going forward.
And within our refining and optimization groups, we saw improvements in yield and inventory execution. In many cases, capturing the full value of these non-capital initiatives requires teamwork within a department, as well as cross-functional coordination. 
Turning to the second quarter, we started to see improvement at the differentials for California heavy crudes, which historically lag foreign heavy crude differentials. While the domestic differentials didn't materialize until late in the first quarter, we do expect to see the benefit during the second quarter. On the product side, I would say, in broad terms, we are seeing demand stability for light products. But clearly, gasoline supply is above last year's inventory level, and also the five-year range.
We believe, like many of you who write about the industry, that unemployment right now is the largest factor in preventing a return to growing gasoline demand. While the increase in unemployment in California has declined, and it appears to be stable, we need to see a sharp decline in that statistic before we expect to see demand growth. Accordingly, I do not believe we will change the corporate philosophy I outlined in our last earnings call. We will continue to manage and focus business execution around safety, reliability and cash conservation. To achieve this, we need to be diligent, flexible and sensitive to changes in the marketplace.
We must deliver on system non-capital initiatives, which we still expect to be in line with our original guidance of $160 million to $170 million. And finally, even though we've reduced our 2010 capital program, we expect to spend approximately $60 million of income improvement, those quick hit projects we've talked about. So we expect to spend $60 million this year.
We expect these small high-return projects located across our entire asset base to improve cash flow and generate real return for our shareholders, particularly since those returns are a little more resilient to margins.
Before I open the call to questions, I want to thank everyone for their support, for their interest and for the great analytical work that you've given to me during my almost 18 years of service here at Tesoro. In any corporation, there are highs and there have certainly been some lows. But nevertheless, it's been a real privilege and honor to be in this position for so many years. I want to thank my management team, and I want to acknowledge the excellent commitment that they've shown to our shareholders. I know Greg Goff and the management team will continue to do an excellent job for our shareholders, and that I'm very confident that you'll enjoy working with and getting to know Greg. 
Finally, just one last thing, in a not too distant future, the other Greg, Greg Wright, is also going to join me in retirement. And I want to take this opportunity, since he won't be participating in future calls, to thank him for his tireless support and wise counsel for so many years. I know that many of you have known Greg for a long time, and I wanted you to have the opportunity to say goodbye. And Greg, would you like to say anything before we take questions?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would, Bruce, thank you. Bruce is correct, and that I will soon be concluding my 15-year career at Tesoro. And if I count it right, some 38 years in the energy industry. I've been humbled by the support I've received during my tenure as CFO. And if you
componenttext:
I would, Bruce, thank you. Bruce is correct, and that I will soon be concluding my 15-year career at Tesoro. And if I count it right, some 38 years in the energy industry. I've been humbled by the support I've received during my tenure as CFO. And if you look at just the Investor Relations area, I began doing Investor Relations back in the dark ages, 1983. And it's been a part of my responsibility, virtually, every year since then. And I'll miss the relationships I have with many of you, and I wish you the very best going forward.
I'm appreciative of the tremendously talented management team and the hard-working employees with whom I've worked. We have accomplished some great things together during some difficult times, and I'll miss the challenge. But I know the new management team will be up to meeting it. Thank you, all, for your support.

componenttext: I think, since we don't have approval yet, it's hard to say that we'd a benefit. I mean, we don't have any baked in our plan really. And so I think once we know where we are and we'll review it with the board, we can talk a little bit more about it. But it's certainly probably more likely to be a third quarter event from a modeling perspective. And I'd say, like most things, I mean, there's going to be a little bit of trial and error in what we're doing here. I mean, I think even with the plan that we're looking at, it'll take us a little bit of time to really fully realize the value of that. We'll see. But I mean, I would expect it would be more of a growing process.

componenttext: The Russian crude is producing at about 350,000 barrels per day. The discounts, we take advantage of being one of the first ones to purchase the crude and getting substantial discounts. The good thing about the ESPO is that it's putting pressure on the Alaskan North Slope crude, which we also buy, and providing us a benefit in that manner.

componenttext: It's a little early. I mean, the production level is supposed to grow, and it may have broader implications all the way around. It's a little early. I was asking a question today about this crude as we were talking, and this is a continuation of a program that we've had now that's five, six years old, of buying these ordinary crudes, being the first buyer. I was told that we processed 100 new crudes or around 100 new crudes. So again, this is one that potentially has some more positive benefits for us because it does maybe put some pressure on more broadly that quality crude in the Pacific area.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: Just in the press release, you alluded too that you're seeing some improvement in gasoline demand since the start of the year. Could you just provide a little bit more color not only from the start of the year but sort of year-over-year? And then, the trends that you're seeing in light of the addition of the increase in ethanol into the California gasoline?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lynn Westfall will be glad to help you with that.
componenttext: Lynn Westfall will be glad to help you with that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, the numbers we got yesterday for February were encouraging. We've had five gasoline showing a year-over-year increase of about 6.6%. January was at 3.2%. So it's moving in the right direction. The issue though is that, that was building o
componenttext: Well, certainly, the numbers we got yesterday for February were encouraging. We've had five gasoline showing a year-over-year increase of about 6.6%. January was at 3.2%. So it's moving in the right direction. The issue though is that, that was building on a very low 2008 numbers, where gasoline was down almost 11%. So the direction is good on gasoline demand, but it's building off of a very low base. Certainly, we're expecting to see what we normally see at this time of the year, which is seasonality in gasoline demand. Typically, second quarter versus first quarter, demand goes up in the neighborhood of 50,000 to 60,000 barrels a day. I think it's fair to say that we're cautiously optimistic about demand. But as long as unemployment stays as high as it is, and I think that's going to be with us for probably most of the rest of this year, we would expect to see significant demand increases. But at least now, we have the direction going right or maybe stable. So I think that's kind of our view on gasoline demand going forward. On your second question, CARB gasoline, we've got four months worth of data right now, but the interpretation of that data can vary. What the data says for four months out of this year, for California refinery, is that CARB gasoline yield, which includes downstream ethanol blending is exactly equal to what it was last year. But overall gasoline yield is up about 3.5%. So right now, it appears from the data, the excess is actually showing up in conventional gasoline. That's the data, and now the interpretation can vary. Interpretations can be that it was caused by turnarounds that are forcing people to be make conventional than CARB. It can be that demand is only being met by CARB gasoline yield, and excess is into conventional. So the economics maybe forcing people to make more conventional in CARB. So overall, gasoline yield, as I said, is up. It's not as up as much as you would expect from the conversion from 5.7% to 10%. It's only up, as I said, about 3.5% versus about 4.5% you'd expect from the ethanol yield. So the data's still young, and we'll look at it, as we go forward, maybe able to get some better conclusions.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following that up, how about what you're seeing on the distillate side, diesel particularly, in terms of demand?
componenttext: Just following that up, how about what you're seeing on the distillate side, diesel particularly, in terms of demand?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the local demand, certainly, isn't what we'd hoped for. But it's getting same picture as gasoline. We saw January go up 2.1%. February is down 1%. I think the major story on diesel demand is local demand, it's export. We've seen, I think, some prett
componenttext: Well, the local demand, certainly, isn't what we'd hoped for. But it's getting same picture as gasoline. We saw January go up 2.1%. February is down 1%. I think the major story on diesel demand is local demand, it's export. We've seen, I think, some pretty good export activity out of the West Coast on distillate in March and continued on in April, primarily going down to South America. So again, I think that's really going to be the picture for distillate demand going forward for the next several months.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, if I could just jump back on one of the things you highlighted, ESPO crude. We've been watching this pretty carefully. And I guess the question we want to ask is, have they been aggressively pricing these crudes in order to get things going?
componenttext: First of all, if I could just jump back on one of the things you highlighted, ESPO crude. We've been watching this pretty carefully. And I guess the question we want to ask is, have they been aggressively pricing these crudes in order to get things going? Or do you think the dynamics that we've seen here are relatively sustainable? And I guess, just as a kind of related question. If I look at the widening of ANS, well, obviously, we're coming into maintenance in Alaska here, I guess, pretty soon. Do you think that kind of dynamic or that kind of discount, again, is something we might see as a more sustainable basis? I believe, ESPO crude are looking at something like trebling the production over the next couple of years. So obviously, we're pretty interested to know how this plays to your market.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, this is Chuck Flagg. I think, initially, we got a very good discount on ESPO as refiners become more aware of the crude, particularly in the Far East. It's putting pressure both on far eastern crudes, and as I said earlier, on the ANS. The ANS
componenttext: Yes, Doug, this is Chuck Flagg. I think, initially, we got a very good discount on ESPO as refiners become more aware of the crude, particularly in the Far East. It's putting pressure both on far eastern crudes, and as I said earlier, on the ANS. The ANS has blown out. As you indicated, we are coming in to the summer maintenance season in Alaska. So we would expect at least directional tightening on the ANS. But again, the ESPO is coming into the West Coast, and I believe it will continue to pressure the Alaskan crude.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: So this was, I guess, a semi-permanent benefit for you guys, going forward? Is that fair to say?
componenttext: So this was, I guess, a semi-permanent benefit for you guys, going forward? Is that fair to say?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair to say.
componenttext: I think that's fair to say.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably, over the longer time, it could be even larger with the increase, as Chuck  pointed out.
componenttext: Probably, over the longer time, it could be even larger with the increase, as Chuck  pointed out.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: My next one is for Lynn. Are you seeing any kind of flow of natural gasoline products going east or sorry, west should I say as a response to the additional ethanol?

componenttext: Doug, this is Chuck again. We're really not seeing nat pour into the West Coast. Clearly, there would be an ability to lend more.

componenttext: That support [ph] the concern? I'm sorry. No, we're not seeing that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: Is there any change at all then in terms of ethanol impact? I mean, I'm thinking about the free octane you guys are basically getting. You know, with no vapor pressure changes. So I'm trying to get a feel at so what that means with the way you run your units or the industry as a whole runs their units?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have taken advantage of shutting some reformer capacity in and gaining on the expenses from that perspective. But as Lynn said, we're not seeing a tremendous increase in the production of gasoline as a result of CARB 4.
componenttext: Well, we have taken advantage of shutting some reformer capacity in and gaining on the expenses from that perspective. But as Lynn said, we're not seeing a tremendous increase in the production of gasoline as a result of CARB 4.

componenttext: Are those coming in the shut-ins, Chuck?

componenttext: Yes, they are. We've shuttered our reformer down both at Golden Eagle and one at Los Angeles.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would be really good news, but it's not.
componenttext: It would be really good news, but it's not.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: The final one for me is just on the CapEx deferrals. I guess, Bruce, in your prepared remarks, you talked about multi-year deferral of regulatory CapEx. Can you just talk about how you've been able to achieve that and maybe a little more granularity as to
componenttext: The final one for me is just on the CapEx deferrals. I guess, Bruce, in your prepared remarks, you talked about multi-year deferral of regulatory CapEx. Can you just talk about how you've been able to achieve that and maybe a little more granularity as to whether that capital is just going to shift into next year? Or if these are actual permanent reductions for capital spending?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think they're going to be permanent, but they're not going to be in the near years. They've really been -- this effort, that's been going on just as I said in my prepared remarks. In order to develop a budget, much of these works done on such a pr
componenttext: I don't think they're going to be permanent, but they're not going to be in the near years. They've really been -- this effort, that's been going on just as I said in my prepared remarks. In order to develop a budget, much of these works done on such a preliminary basis. And with the dynamic processes that are in the market and the way we're looking at rescheduling and better procurement, we've found some ways with some permanent  NOx credits to do some things that we didn't anticipate. So it really is -- it's a lot of solutions that come together but at the end, you're probably going to have spend some dollars. Eric,  do you want to comment on or...

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me expound on that a little bit. We had a project. It was quite a large project for  NOx control  in Los Angeles, and it involved a number of pieces that were relatively low return energy savings around cogeneration and boiler replacements. When we de
componenttext: Let me expound on that a little bit. We had a project. It was quite a large project for  NOx control  in Los Angeles, and it involved a number of pieces that were relatively low return energy savings around cogeneration and boiler replacements. When we deconstructed that project in this environment with the lower energy costs and a more constrained capital, we found a combination of commercial and more efficient investments to achieve the necessary  NOx control. So we got the  NOx control  done with a combination of perpetual  NOx credits that we bought in the market at a good price and a much less reduced capital investment. At some point in the future, but I think outside, our current planning horizon, we'll still go back and look at those boiler and cogeneration projects. But I wouldn't be concerned about them in the current planning horizon.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the key is really through this low margin cycle, where we think they -- for whether it's one or two or three years. We've done some things to permanently change what we're going to do to be able to generate free cash flow.
componenttext: I think the key is really through this low margin cycle, where we think they -- for whether it's one or two or three years. We've done some things to permanently change what we're going to do to be able to generate free cash flow.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
