componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Edward Westlake with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Sean Kelly  on behalf of Ed, he's tied up on another call. I wanted to chat a little bit about demand. You guys have done a good job answering -- my question actually, on your website, you have unemployment data and other gasoline and die
componenttext: This is actually Sean Kelly  on behalf of Ed, he's tied up on another call. I wanted to chat a little bit about demand. You guys have done a good job answering -- my question actually, on your website, you have unemployment data and other gasoline and diesel demand data. I was wondering if you're seeing anything in the ports, anything on the ground that's kind of an indicator to what's going on with the distillate  demand?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Lynn Westfall. At this point in time, I think it's the same picture as we're seeing with gasoline demand. It looks stable but not rising. As far as the liftings [ph] at the port, they're going up from where they were. They're certainly not at the
componenttext: This is Lynn Westfall. At this point in time, I think it's the same picture as we're seeing with gasoline demand. It looks stable but not rising. As far as the liftings [ph] at the port, they're going up from where they were. They're certainly not at the level they used to be. The driver for distillate demand that is coming up on us shortly will be the planning season. So I think that's good. As far as internal demand to the West Coast, I'm not talking about export demand, I think that will be the primary factor that we'll be looking at in the second quarter.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: And building back on the CapEx or the capital program. I was actually at your Analyst Day in New York in the fall. With regards to your kind of out to 2013 guidance, the question was kind of answered previously, but what are you looking at in terms of the
componenttext: And building back on the CapEx or the capital program. I was actually at your Analyst Day in New York in the fall. With regards to your kind of out to 2013 guidance, the question was kind of answered previously, but what are you looking at in terms of the total spend out in 2012 and 2013?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Frank can kind of chime in as well. But we are -- if the question is kind of where we're pushing out of this year, we're going to see it in the next two years. I don't think we see that kind of a trend. I think our outlooks are still pretty consistent
componenttext: And Frank can kind of chime in as well. But we are -- if the question is kind of where we're pushing out of this year, we're going to see it in the next two years. I don't think we see that kind of a trend. I think our outlooks are still pretty consistent in the outer years from what you saw on the previous plans.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would agree. There's certainly nothing beyond the quick hit capital program that we've got that we may find other ways of adding to that, but it's going to be small. And probably, directionally things are still down as we've find this process being much
componenttext: I would agree. There's certainly nothing beyond the quick hit capital program that we've got that we may find other ways of adding to that, but it's going to be small. And probably, directionally things are still down as we've find this process being much more successful than maybe we expect it to be. A lot of those projects just maybe haven't seen where we're going to be in the review. And of course, procurements will be different. But directionally, probably still down.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Have you given any other guidance with respect to Hawaii and how do you continue to view that refinery?
componenttext: Have you given any other guidance with respect to Hawaii and how do you continue to view that refinery?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't given any other guidance on Hawaii. I think that in one of the comments that I made, we continue -- we've been very active in looking at all of our assets, and it goes to really the capital and the operations and in that particular instance, so
componenttext: We haven't given any other guidance on Hawaii. I think that in one of the comments that I made, we continue -- we've been very active in looking at all of our assets, and it goes to really the capital and the operations and in that particular instance, some of the ways that we market product. I think they were making progress in across all those fronts with our customers. And I do think that with regard to why that we're closer to being able to potentially unlock some additional value there. So I think that Hawaii is still a focus for us. A lot of efforts going into determining how we can improve the profitability of that on a sustainable basis. And I think it's sort of multi-functional, and I think we'll end up being successful in coming back to describe some of the things we've been able to do.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: On product demand, it's really on the flip side of Chi's question. Latin demand for incremental product has also been positive due to refining outages and lower hydro levels. I was wondering if you could discuss that arbitrage or how to sort of maybe bene
componenttext: On product demand, it's really on the flip side of Chi's question. Latin demand for incremental product has also been positive due to refining outages and lower hydro levels. I was wondering if you could discuss that arbitrage or how to sort of maybe benefiting or any thoughts really heading into Latin American winter here?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Evan, Chuck Flagg. We have seen a tremendous demand pull particularly coming from Chile and Mexico in particular, where there's some refinery downtime. We've been putting cargoes together and shipping it down there as have our competitors. So it's really
componenttext: Evan, Chuck Flagg. We have seen a tremendous demand pull particularly coming from Chile and Mexico in particular, where there's some refinery downtime. We've been putting cargoes together and shipping it down there as have our competitors. So it's really putting an incremental demand on the West Coast, which I think is contributing to our higher margins that we've seen thus far.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about on the flip side? If you heading east. I mean, with lower utilization, can you increase runs, secure delivery through Calnev or maybe how do you think about Calnev versus the proposed UNEV  since you're on both sides of that market?
componenttext: How about on the flip side? If you heading east. I mean, with lower utilization, can you increase runs, secure delivery through Calnev or maybe how do you think about Calnev versus the proposed UNEV  since you're on both sides of that market?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the demand in Las Vegas, well it had been growing, has certainly slowed. UNEV, as it now stands, we have not committed any barrels to it. And so it remains to be seen as far as how many barrels actually are committed to UNEV.
componenttext: Well, the demand in Las Vegas, well it had been growing, has certainly slowed. UNEV, as it now stands, we have not committed any barrels to it. And so it remains to be seen as far as how many barrels actually are committed to UNEV.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what about now in terms of going through Calnev?
componenttext: And what about now in terms of going through Calnev?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't put a whole lot of barrels into Calnev ourselves. That line is currently full. So at the margin, barrels tend to get trapped. But again, demand is very much down in Las Vegas. It's one of the most impacted areas in the country.
componenttext: We don't put a whole lot of barrels into Calnev ourselves. That line is currently full. So at the margin, barrels tend to get trapped. But again, demand is very much down in Las Vegas. It's one of the most impacted areas in the country.

componenttext: It's really the incentive compensation accrual. It's a change of that method. That's a principle. There's a little bit of stock-based compensation, but it's partially driven that change in compensation method. And then we also have Bill  Finnerty, you may remember left the corporation. And so we took a charge relative to that. So really sort of three sort of big baskets there. The incentive compensation was about $3 million, and so that will continue and that's build into the guidance that Scott gave you.

componenttext: Bruce, on the latest cut in the CapEx from the 600 to 500 to 525, is there any particular project that you can share, say, what that maybe?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Everett. The latest cut really isn't in any one big project. It's probably scattered over 15 to 20 smaller projects. And it's part of that process that we go through, where we look very carefully at each project and make sure we haven't got any ex
componenttext: This is Everett. The latest cut really isn't in any one big project. It's probably scattered over 15 to 20 smaller projects. And it's part of that process that we go through, where we look very carefully at each project and make sure we haven't got any excess capital going into that program. So there isn't a single big project now. It's scattered over a range of projects.

componenttext: I have no reason to believe that DD&A expense wont be. I don't know that for a fact. But we have -- on overall forecast, we are building that way. headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: This is Everett. For your modeling purposes, what you're using now in terms of cash fixed operating expense will be similar and maybe slightly lower. The variable cost, of course, is down because we're not running the units. So we can give you more precise numbers, but we're continuing to, as we've said, pay the operating costs.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I need to think about that. I'm a little reluctant to start isolating expenses here because we've got two refineries that are combined in there. And for competitive reasons, I'm not sure we're going to break that out. I need to think about that. I'll thin
componenttext: I need to think about that. I'm a little reluctant to start isolating expenses here because we've got two refineries that are combined in there. And for competitive reasons, I'm not sure we're going to break that out. I need to think about that. I'll think five minutes before I retire this afternoon. But I'm not sure about that information if for that reason because one of things I don't want to do is start doing too much around that, that starts to give competitive information relative to what the other refinery might be. So I'm a little sensitive to that. I've talked to the team here about that even in the second quarter. So just please give us a little time to think about that, and we'll let you know where we come out.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Gilman with Benchmark.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Gilman with Benchmark.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

componenttext: It's Eli Bauman on behalf of Mark, actually. I was wondering how much flexibility you have to defer LA-related regulatory projects?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: Everett, I can't answer that question.
componenttext: Everett, I can't answer that question.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's awfully perspective. We, of course, are going to stay in compliance with all the regulatory requirements around Los Angeles, and that's the first driver. And the best guidance we have today is what you've got in our forward plans, and I would use t
componenttext: That's awfully perspective. We, of course, are going to stay in compliance with all the regulatory requirements around Los Angeles, and that's the first driver. And the best guidance we have today is what you've got in our forward plans, and I would use that. But I think in the back of your minds, as we continue to look at that process, we tend to find ways to reduce it, but we can't say that at this point.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: You look at the first quarter, and just when we were looking at that in the fourth quarter, I mean, we made a significant reduction in the first quarter this year. I think that what I said earlier about when you look at the out years and we look at capita
componenttext: You look at the first quarter, and just when we were looking at that in the fourth quarter, I mean, we made a significant reduction in the first quarter this year. I think that what I said earlier about when you look at the out years and we look at capital, and you look at this low margin environment, we set a new standard for ourselves, and this will be even when margins improved. But the process we've got going on we believe will continue to find ways to reduce the capital investment. And particularly, capital investments associated as with its non-productive regulatory capital. The safety, the reliability, we just have the fundamental. There's not one meeting that Everett and I go to that we don't talk about we're not going to compromise that. So it's all about finding other ways to save money, and I just think it's part of what we're going to do and you're going to continue to see revisions that go down. If all of a sudden, the economy is so robust, you might see changes going up because the materials and labor get more expensive than where we planned, but that's not the environment we're in.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to thank everybody again. I appreciate all the very, very great -- I both appreciate the kind comments that so many people made. I think the many wishes for a good retirement, the only person that may not be happy about that is my wife, Gail, who h
componenttext: I want to thank everybody again. I appreciate all the very, very great -- I both appreciate the kind comments that so many people made. I think the many wishes for a good retirement, the only person that may not be happy about that is my wife, Gail, who has already told me that I need to find something else to do. But I want to tell you all, once again, that it's truly been a pleasure. I know that the second quarter conference call will be a little bit more unusual, having done this for a long time. But I actually think that we're on the verge of starting to see some very positive changes in the marketplace. As we've talked, just if you look at everything statistically, a 12-month comparison is like day and night anymore. I mean the world was so different 12 months ago, just as we look at all statistics and as people look about coming out of the recession and the statistics still don't show that we're coming out of recession. I think that we are positioned, and I think that the continued focus on cash and being able to employ cash more effectively for shareholders is going to continue, and it's going to continue -- it's going to start to show some real benefits here in the last half of the year. So once again, thank you very much. And I'll be on your end of the phone listening to the second quarter. Operator, that's it.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation’s Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. A brief question and answer session will follow the formal presentation. (Operator instructions).It is
componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation’s Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. A brief question and answer session will follow the formal presentation. (Operator instructions).
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Louie Rubiola Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation, thank you Mr. Rubiola you may begin.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Jacky, good morning everyone and welcome to today’s conference call to discuss our second quarter 2010 earnings. Joining me today are Greg Goff, President and CEO, Everett Lewis, Executive Vice President and COO and Scott Spendlove, Senior Vic
componenttext:
Thank you Jacky, good morning everyone and welcome to today’s conference call to discuss our second quarter 2010 earnings. Joining me today are Greg Goff, President and CEO, Everett Lewis, Executive Vice President and COO and Scott Spendlove, Senior Vice President and CFO.
While we will not be referencing slides during the call, we do have a set of slides which was filed with the SEC today. These slides along with other financial disclosure should help you in analyzing our results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com.
Please refer to the forward-looking statements in the earnings slides, which says statements made during this call that refer to management’s expectations and/or future predictions are forward-looking statements, intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Act. As there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations.
With that, I will turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Louie, good morning everyone and thanks for joining us on the call today. As everyone knows I joined Tesoro about three months ago. The first three months have been challenging and exciting and we have embarked on a very focused and ambitious agend
componenttext:
Thanks Louie, good morning everyone and thanks for joining us on the call today. As everyone knows I joined Tesoro about three months ago. The first three months have been challenging and exciting and we have embarked on a very focused and ambitious agenda to drive fundamental improvement in the business.
Later in the call today, I will talk a little bit about some of those key initiatives. And then during the fourth quarter of this year we will also provide a very compelling plan to deliver shareholder value during our analyst meeting.
Today, we are pleased to report second quarter earnings of $0.47 per share or $0.30 per diluted share for one time benefit of $0.17. These earnings were achieved with Anacortes refinery idled and then Mandan refinery down for a planned turnaround, as industry spreads improved significantly, during the quarter and our capture rate also improved. 
The Tesoro index in the quarter was nearly double what we saw in the first quarter, and it was up about 15% in the second quarter of last year. We saw positive signs of economic recovery during the quarter specifically on the West Coast port traffic and rail activity, which we believe supported higher distillate margin.
Gasoline spreads meanwhile continues to suffer from weak demand as unemployment in California remains high.
Capture rate throughout our system were up significantly in the quarter, driven by 3 or 4 key things. One strong commercial and wholesale margins, two improved crude differentials, three an ethanol discount to Gasoline, of about $0.55 per gallon, which improved the margin on ethanol blended gasoline. And finally as a result of the shutdown of the Anacortes refinery. We were still able to profitably meet our customer requirements in the Pacific Northwest.
Retail marketing margins were also strong during the quarter as spot price fell more rapidly than street prices. And of course our throughput rates during the quarter, were down significantly from last year second quarter as we tided the Anacortes refinery following the fire on the naphtha hydrotreater.
Additionally our Mandan refinery successfully completed its propane turnaround during the quarter it’s probably important to note about the Mandan refinery it’s on about a 6.5 year plus turn around cycle.
Anacortes remained ideal today, but we have begun work to repair the damaged units. That work is progressing well and on schedule, and we expect the plant should be operational as early as September. 
Meanwhile, we continue to work closely with the investigators regarding the incident. We have successfully moved unfinished product produced at Anacortes during April to our other refineries for further processing.
Additionally, we were able to devour water borne crew cargos heading to Anacortes to our California refinery and we continue to successfully supply our customers with products either sourced from out [control] refineries for our third party purchases. 
Regarding Anacortes, it is also important to note that we expect the financial impact of this incident to be limited to our insurance deductibles. And finally I can’t stress enough how thankful we are to our employees at the Anacortes facility, they have worked admirably to get us through this terrible tragedy.
Despite the improvement in margins and earnings during the quarter, we remain focused on our core objectives of driving operations excellence in capital discipline. And while we have seen some signs of economic improvement, high unemployment in California and excess refining capacity in US still way on margins and generally we continue to plan for our margin environment, similar to what we saw in 2009.
As such we remained focused on operating our assets safely and reliably optimizing the system and allowing local demand to be the primary driver of production and yield.
We remain focused on maximizing cash flows and delivering the expected results from our capital and non-capital initiative.
As we announced in our press release, our capital spending including turn arounds in the second quarter was about $140 million and our estimate for this year is now in the range $475 million $500 million. 
We also expect future capital spending to be lower than guidance previously given. We remain committed to investing in safety, reliability, environmental protection and to our quick hit capital program announced last call. However, we continue to look for and find ways to capture advantages and lower our overall capital spending. 
Examples of where we have been able to reduce our capital spending requirements, while still achieving objectives of the necessary work includes NOx reductions at our Los Angeles refinery and bending reductions across our whole refining system.
As we have mentioned on the first quarter call, we originally expected to comply with NOx reduction requirements through significant investments in a co-generation facility and boiler replacements.
We have since discovered that we will be able to meet our requirements through more efficient investments and the purchase of perpetual credits. This has significantly changed the scope of the multi-year projects that originally totaled about $350 million.
Similarly, we continue to assess our plans for bending compliance and reduced our expect spend by about $15 million and have found ways to push the spending out through 2013, which is about a year longer than we previously expected.
We will be completing our annual capital planning process in the fall and expect to revive our guidance for 2011 and beyond at that point.
From an income capital perspective, we continue to execute are (inaudible) capital program, we are on track to spend about $50 million to $60 million in 2010, and we expect to realize a total of $25 million in related EBITDA this year.
Also, we continue to make very good progress on our $165 million non-capital initiatives for this year, and having realized about half of that target improvements year to date. 
To further strengthen our competitive position, we announced yesterday, changes to our corporate over head and benefit plans that when fully implemented by the end of this year will have a significant impact on our expenses, cash flow and future liabilities.
These changes to our corporate overhead include a reduction in force and other overhead efficiency improvements that we expect will reduce total over head cost by $40 million to $50 million annually.
In addition, we concluded a study of our benefits programs during the quarter and made changes that we expect will reduce our on going benefit expenses by $80 million to $90 million annually. The changes are primarily to post retirement medical and life insurance benefits that bring us more in line with our piers and reduce the estimated post retirement benefit liabilities on our balance sheet.
The change to the post retirement life benefits allowed us to record a pre tax gain of $43 million net of severance accruals during the quarter. And because the savings are mostly related to accruals of future obligation, the cash [baiting] started out small. In the $5 million to $10 million range, but then they grow to an estimated $25 million annually in about 10 years. 
As significant is P&L and cash savings are, is the reduction in estimated post retirement benefit obligation on our balance sheet. In round numbers these changes will reduce both liabilities from a projected $900 million at the end of this year to just under $600 million, and where that liability was projected to grow to nearly to $1.2 billion by 2014, we are now projecting that liability to stay relatively constant and about $600 million, so at about 50% of the level that would have grown to.
Finally, let me update you on the status of our actions to improve the pricing for the fuel that we supply to Hawaii electric.
As we have mentioned last quarter the Tesoro and Hawaii electric public utility reached an agreement on a new pricing formula related to low sulfur fuel oil sales we are still awaiting approval from the Hawaiian Public Utility Commission. However, based on eco findings with the PUC, a [hearing] is expected sometime in the fourth quarter. At this point we prefer not to provide any financial guidance related to the new pricing formula until we have the final approval through the PUC.
Today, we believe we have the right assets in the right markets, and we see significant opportunity to strengthen out competitive position by improving our cost structure and driving improvements with our capital and non capital initiative we also continue to believe that structurally the West Coast is one of the most attractive markets and offers some advantages that we like.
Having said that, we have initiated a comprehensive strategic review of our business and as I talked about earlier we plan to discuss our strategic plans at the fall analyst day event. 
With that, I’ll turn the call over to Scott Spendlove our CFO for more detailed discussion of our quarterly results and to provide guidance for the third quarter, and then at the end I’ll comeback and provide some concluding comments, Scott.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Greg, during the second quarter, we reported net income of $67 million, or $0.47 per diluted share. These results include one time after tax benefits of $24 million or $0.17 per diluted share. There are three primary items that account for these ad
componenttext:
Thanks Greg, during the second quarter, we reported net income of $67 million, or $0.47 per diluted share. These results include one time after tax benefits of $24 million or $0.17 per diluted share. There are three primary items that account for these adjustments. Greg already mentioned the $43 million net that is primarily related to our post retirement benefit changes. After tax these net benefits changes is a $26 million credit earnings. 
Also in the quarter, there were one time after tax charges of $7 million. Related to expense accruals and asset write offs at our Anacortes refinery. Finally, we took an after tax benefit of $5 million, related to a state tax settlement arising from exploration and production activities of Tesoro over 15 years ago. 
Adjusted for special items, that leaves us with net income of $43 million or $0.30 per diluted share. Segment operating income was $180 million for the quarter. $153 million net of the special items, up significantly from the $11 million, we reported for the quarter last year and driven by the margins gains, Greg described earlier. 
Our manufacturing cost in the second quarter, were $248 million in line with the first quarter of this year. We ended the second quarter with a cash balance of $191 million and $713 million of availability on the revolving credit facility. Once again we were under on our net facility during the quarter.
At the end of the quarter, our total debt to total capitalization ratio was 37%. Year-to-date, cash is down over $200 million as CapEx changes and working capital and interest payments, outpaced EBITDA and tax refunds.
As Greg mentioned earlier we spend a $140 million in capital expenditures during the quarter. This was up from the first quarter, primarily due to the full plant turnaround at our Mandan refinery. 
Looking forward to the remainder of 2010, the only material turnaround work we have is currently under way at our Hawaii refinery.
Turning to the quarter, we see gasoline demand on the West Coast remaining stagnant as California unemployment remains at its peak of around 12.5%, some 3% above the national average.
Supply changes, however are balancing low demand with crude around gasoline production and gasoline inventories all close to their five years lows in July. As a result so far in July the West Coast crack is up more than $3 per barrel over July of last year and the gasoline against difference for the Gulf Coast is close to its five year high for the month at over $0.25 per gallon.
I’ll close with providing guidance for the third quarter for your modeling purposes. In these assumption we have assumed the Anacortes refinery remains idle during the months of July and August, where the restart currently expected for September.
We estimate throughput in thousands of barrels per day to be 75 to 85, in the Pacific Northwest, 55 to 65 in the mid Pacific, 110 to 120 in the mid continent and 240 to 250 in the California region. OpEx guidance for the third quarter and dollars per barrel is as follows: $745 in the Pacific Northwest, $375 in the Mid Pacific, $330 in the Mid continent and 710 in the California region.
Our depreciation for refining is estimated at $95 million, an additional second quarter guidance items include corporate expense of $37 million, which includes the savings expected from recent changes to our corporate overhead structure and interest expense before interest income of $40 million.
With that, I’ll turn the call back over to Greg for closing comments. Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: As I stated earlier when we began this call, we were actually excited about the challenges and the opportunity however we also recognize that excess capacity in the refining industry will continue to put pressure on refining margins, therefore we are very
componenttext:
As I stated earlier when we began this call, we were actually excited about the challenges and the opportunity however we also recognize that excess capacity in the refining industry will continue to put pressure on refining margins, therefore we are very committed and focused to personnel and process safety efforts to drive continued improvement, our effort to lower our cost structure, add value with aggressive non capital and quick capital program and a very disciplined approach to cash management.
Thank you for joining me on the call today. And with that, we’ll now take questions.

One was that you think you got the right assets in the right places. But on the other hand you are going to carry a complete strategic review.

componenttext: Yeah we got that regarding the question on the right assets in the right places. The markets that we operate in, we fundamentally like those markets for a variety of reasons, regarding the look at the assets where we need to go back in and look at where we can drive improvements in the assets from a competitive standpoint in to really capture more value so, hopefully it wasn’t a contradiction as much as just a point that in general we like the Western part of the United States in those markets, however we need to get the performance of certain assets up at a higher level and so they as you know some of the assets are in niche markets and so we intended to further look at ways to capture more valuable on an basis and how we can integrated it with our overall system.

componenttext: During the second quarter we did have some operational hiccupps as you properly stated at the Los Angeles refinery it created a little bit of a loss profit opportunity for us, but if you take a step back and look at the overall programs we have been making good progress since the refinery was acquired to really bring it up to our standards to operate to improve reliability to improve the integrity of the assets, and we continue to focus on the programs where we get the greatest benefit from doing that, and so they have actually come up with some pretty innovative ways to help manage the required capital to get there and at the same time achieve the objectives of proving the overall assets so it is probably one of our highest priority assets to really look at and be able to drive the improvements we need to, but also be very cognizant of the capital that is takes to do that.

componenttext:
Some of things we do are a lot around the basic infrastructure and refinery. And lot of our capital around LA is improving that basic infrastructure. The one example is the average that we had in the quarter was driven by an electrical average. 
We have a good generation plant in the refinery and we have got some money we are spending to improve the controls. And the ability of that system to stay online, when we have any disruption from the electric supply. So it’s primarily around infrastructure and making sure that that infrastructure is consistent with our standards for reliability and safety in our refinery going forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well from a business interruption standpoint and then we, as you are aware we have insurance on both the assets and into business interruption and we are working through with the insurance companies on those claims right now. So we haven’t put anything
componenttext:
Well from a business interruption standpoint and then we, as you are aware we have insurance on both the assets and into business interruption and we are working through with the insurance companies on those claims right now. So we haven’t put anything in our numbers to get any payment back on the actual damage to the facilities once we have collect on that claim. And our business interruption we are working through that process with the insurer’s to be able to process the claim, which as you probably are aware is either based upon 60 days or the $25 million.
And we believe (based) if you go back and look at the second quarter you can kind of see what the results would have been, if the facility would have been running and the results of that, claim. So we are already working through with the insurance adjusters and hope to get that resolved, as we move through the second half of this year.

So at this point in time there is nothing that we are aware of that would preclude us from making that restart.

Yes Jeff, I think throughput maybe the thing that’s driving in our per barrel basis, a little higher we got the light turn around, we got. Anacortes is still down in July and August coming up sometime in September.
But beyond that I don’t know if anything that we would expect to drive the absolute cost higher.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think in both of refineries that you are talking about there are additional crude’s coming to market over time. That will have an impact on the business and that’s something that we look at all the time and determine how that availability of th
componenttext:
Well I think in both of refineries that you are talking about there are additional crude’s coming to market over time. That will have an impact on the business and that’s something that we look at all the time and determine how that availability of the crude the impact of the differentials the ones that we enjoyed a day.
How that will be impacted in the future as we go forward. So in the short term we don’t see any immediate impact although we are gaining some advantages by some crude that we can supply to the Salt Lake City refinery. But longer term that’s part of our strategic review to determine how we position ourselves as additional crude comes to the market and the impact it will have on the differentials for the supply to those refineries.

componenttext:
Both those questions, Paul we’ll be able to talk more clearly and specifically later this year when we get through to get a better chance to look at it. But around the retail part of the business, because of the markets that we operate in, we need to be integrated between our refining and marketing to support that business, that integration.
For the gasoline is extremely important to us so how we do that becomes important and so today having some of our own retail is one of the things we do. But as we go through our strategic review, we love to see what is the way that, that support and integrated position in the markets that we are in and that will have a, that will have this determined that will, the retail business place going forward. So we’ll talk more about that later this year. 
Around ethanol as you know we have requirement to purchase ethanol a pretty significant amount of ethanol and we’ll look how we do that. We actually like being in the market to go and inquire our needs and not necessarily to be owners of ethanol plants that’s something that right now is not in our strategy.

componenttext: The guidance that we gave regarding 2011, was that our CapEx should be and about the same ballpark numbers that we see for 2010 and one of the big changes for 2011 that helps a key part of that is the co-generation plant, that was in the plan last year around the Los Angeles refinery so that and we are still working through all the details of that but as we worked through our budgeting profits right now we are it looks like we are going to be able to come in and about the same area and so that kind of [related] to us but regarding the capital improvement things and that the plan that was laid out last year we see that to be very valued accretive to what we are doing and so we fully intent to be able to build by the entire capital plans for 2011 and have the spend that was projected as well as the benefits of flow through to EBITDA because of the return on those projects.

componenttext:
Right now Paul I made the point pretty clear at the beginning of the call is that when that overly optimistic under market I mean we see the market probably a lot differently than most people so what we fundamentally believe in is that we see opportunities to drive pretty significant improvement in the business that we as a company need to go in and be able to execute that will provide an opportunity for us to be a buyer in the market place. 
So for example, the first that we’ve taken here to go in and improve our cost structure. We fully intend to continue to do that and lay out plans into 2011, how we’ll be able to drive further improvements in the cost structure? 
We have a good program to on the non-capital improvements to drive value through the way we manage the value chains and make the decisions from crude selection all the way to the [streak] which we believed add value. And then finally by being able to really have a very disciplined and focused approach on our required capital spent and maintain the integrity of our assets.
And at the same time be able to re-deploy some capital to drive additional EBITDA will help our underlying performance, so kind of in summary, if we can execute well the things that we can control we believe we’ll perform at a higher level than what we have been.

Regarding the new crude’s we of course have a program always looking for new crude’s, we are always looking for attractive crude’s we have a very flexible system and we think its one of our advantages that we can be a first mover often time in new crude’s and take advantage of that. We don’t think it’s a good idea for us to share it specifically crude by crude what we are doing in a market because its is a very competitive environment. 
In the past quarter we ran over 30 crews in our system which is a wide variety of crude’s and some of those were new crude’s. So we continue to follow that program and get some benefit from it.

componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Louie Rubiola, Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation. Thank you. Mr. Rubiol
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the Tesoro Corporation Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Louie Rubiola, Director of Investor Relations for Tesoro Corporation. Thank you. Mr. Rubiola, you may begin.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2010 earnings. Joining me today are Greg Goff, President and CEO, Everett Lewis, Executive Vice President and COO; and Scott Spendlove, Senior
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to today's conference call to discuss our second quarter 2010 earnings. Joining me today are Greg Goff, President and CEO, Everett Lewis, Executive Vice President and COO; and Scott Spendlove, Senior Vice President and CFO. 
While we will not be referencing slides during the call, we do have a set of slides which was filed with the SEC today. These slides, along with other financial disclosure, should help you in analyzing our results and can be found on our website at tsocorp.com. Please refer to the forward-looking statements in the earnings slides, which says statements made during this call that refer to management’s expectations and/or future predictions are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions of the Securities Act, as there are many factors which could cause results to differ from our expectations. 
With that, I will turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Louie. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call today. As everyone knows, I joined Tesoro about three months ago. The first three months had been challenging and exciting, and we have embarked on a very focused and ambitious a
componenttext:
Thanks, Louie. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call today. As everyone knows, I joined Tesoro about three months ago. The first three months had been challenging and exciting, and we have embarked on a very focused and ambitious agenda to drive fundamental improvement in the business. Later in the call today, I will talk a little bit about some of those key initiatives. And then during the fourth quarter of this year, we will also provide a very compelling plan to deliver shareholder value during our Analyst Meeting. 
Today, we are pleased to report second quarter earnings of $0.47 per share or $0.30 per diluted share for one-time benefits of $0.17. These earnings were achieved with the Anacortes refinery idled and the Mandan refinery down for plant turnaround as industry spreads improved significantly during the quarter, and our capture rates also improved. 
The Tesoro Index in the quarter was nearly double what we saw in the first quarter, and it was up about 15% from the second quarter of last year. We saw positive signs of economic recovery during the quarter, specifically on the West Coast port traffic and rail activity, which we believe supported higher diesel margins. Gasoline spreads, meanwhile, continue to suffer from weak demand as unemployment in California remains high.
Capture rates throughout our system were up significantly in the quarter, driven by three or four key things: one, strong commercial and wholesale margins; two, improved crude differentials; three, an ethanol discount to gasoline of about $0.55 per gallon, which improved the margin on ethanol-blended gasoline; and finally, as a result of the shutdown of the Anacortes refinery, we were still able to profitably meet our customer requirements in the Pacific Northwest.
Retail marketing margins were also strong during the quarter, as spot prices fell more rapidly than street prices. And of course, our throughput rates during the quarter were down significantly from last year's second quarter as we idled the Anacortes refinery following the fire on the naptha hydrotreater. Additionally, our Mandan refinery successfully completed its full-plant turnaround during the quarter. It's probably important to note about the Mandan refinery is it's on about a 6.5 year-plus turnaround cycle.
Anacortes remains idled today, but we have begun work to repair the damaged units. That work is progressing well and on schedule, and we expect the plant should be operational as early as September. Meanwhile, we continue to work closely with the investigators regarding the incident.
We have successfully moved unfinished products produced at Anacortes during April to our other refineries for further processing. Additionally, we were able to divert water-borne crude cargoes heading to Anacortes to our California refineries, and we continue to successfully supply our customers with products either sourced from our Tesoro refineries or third-party purchases. Regarding Anacortes, it is also important to note that we expect the financial impact of this incident to be limited to our insurance deductibles. 
And finally, I can't stress enough how thankful we are to our employees at the Anacortes facility. They worked admirably to get us through this terrible tragedy. 
Despite the improvement in margins and earnings during the quarter, we remain focused on our core objective of driving operations excellence and capital discipline. And while we have seen some signs of economic improvement, high unemployment in California and excess refining capacity in the U.S. still weigh on margins. And generally, we continue to plan for a margin environment similar to what we saw in 2009.
As such, we remain focused on operating our assets safely and reliably, optimizing the system and allowing local demand to be the primary driver of production and yield. We remain focused on maximizing cash flows and delivering the expected results from our capital and non-capital initiatives.
As we announced in our press release, our capital spending, including turnarounds in the second quarter, was about $140 million, and our estimate for this year is now in the range of $475 million to $500 million. We also expect future capital spending to be lower than guidance previously given. We remain committed to investing in safety, reliability, environmental protection and to our quick-hit capital program announced last fall. However, we continue to look for and find ways to capture advantages and lower our overall capital spending.
Examples of where we've been able to reduce our capital spending requirements while still achieving the objectives of the necessary work include NOx reductions at our Los Angeles refinery and benzene reductions across our whole refining system. As was mentioned on the first quarter call, we originally expected to comply with NOx reductions requirements through significant investments in a cogeneration facility and boiler replacements. We have since discovered that we will be able to meet our requirements through more efficient investments and the purchase of perpetual credits. This has significantly changed the scope of the multi-year projects that originally totaled about $315 million.
Similarly, we continue to assess our plans for benzene compliance and have reduced our expected spend by about $15 million and have found ways to push the spending out through 2013, which is about a year longer than we previously expected. We will be completing our annual capital planning process in the fall and expect to revise our guidance for 2011 and beyond at that point. 
From an income capital perspective, we continue to execute our quick-hit capital program. We are on track to spend about $50 million to $60 million in 2010, and we expect to realize a total of $25 million in related EBITDA this year. Also, we continue to make very good progress on our $165 million non-capital initiatives for this year and having realized about half of that target improvements year-to-date.
To further strengthen our competitive position, we announced yesterday changes to our corporate overhead and benefit plans that, when fully implemented by the end of this year, will have a significant impact on our expenses, cash flow and future liabilities. These changes to our corporate overhead include a reduction in force and other overhead efficiency improvements that we expect to reduce total overhead costs by $40 million to $50 million annually. 
In addition, we concluded a study of our benefits programs during the quarter and made changes that we expect will reduce our ongoing benefit expenses by $80 million to $90 million annually. The changes are primarily to post-retirement medical and life insurance benefits that bring us more in line with our peers and reduce the estimated post-retirement benefit liabilities on our balance sheet. The change to the post-retirement life benefits allow us to record a pretax gain of $43 million, net of severance accrual during the quarter. And because our savings are mostly related to accruals of future obligations, the cash savings start out small in the $5 million to $10 million range, but then they grow at an estimated $25 million annually in about 10 years.
As significant as the P&L and cash savings are is the reduction in estimated post-retirement benefit obligations on our balance sheet. In round numbers, these changes will reduce both liabilities from a projected $900 million at the end of this year to just under $600 million. And where that liability was projected to grow to nearly $1.2 billion by 2014, we're now projecting that liability to stay relatively constant at about $600 million, so at about 50% of the level it would have grown to. 
Finally, let me update you on the status of our actions to improve the pricing for the fuel oil that we supply to Hawaii Electric. As was mentioned last quarter, Tesoro and Hawaii Electric Public Utility reached an agreement on a new pricing formula related to low sulfur fuel oil sales. We are still awaiting approval from the Hawaiian Public Utility Commission (sic) [Hawaiian Public Utilities Commission]. However, based on HECO findings with the PUC, a ruling is expected sometime in the fourth quarter. At this point, we prefer not to provide any financial guidance related to the new pricing formula until we have the final approval through the PUC. 
Today, we believe we have the right assets in the right markets, and we see significant opportunity to strengthen our competitive position by improving our cost structure and driving improvements with our capital and non-capital initiatives. We also continue to believe that structurally, the West Coast is one of the most attractive markets and offer some advantages that we like. Having said that, we have initiated a comprehensive strategic review of our business. And as I talked about earlier, we plan to discuss our strategic plans at the fall Analyst Day event. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott Spendlove, our CFO, for a more detailed discussion of our quarterly results and to provide guidance for the third quarter. And then at the end, I'll come back and provide some concluding comments. Scott?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. During the second quarter, we reported net income of $67 million or $0.47 per diluted share. These results include one-time after-tax benefits of $24 million or $0.17 per diluted share. There are three primary items that account for these ad
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. During the second quarter, we reported net income of $67 million or $0.47 per diluted share. These results include one-time after-tax benefits of $24 million or $0.17 per diluted share. There are three primary items that account for these adjustments. Greg already mentioned the $43 million net that's primarily related to our post-retirement benefit changes. After tax, these net benefits, the changes is a $26 million credit earnings.
Also in the quarter, there were one-time after-tax charges of $7 million related to expense accruals and asset write-offs at our Anacortes refinery. Finally, we took an after-tax benefit of $5 million related to a state tax settlement, arising from exploration and production activities of Tesoro over 15 years ago. Adjusted for special items, that leaves us with net income of $43 million or $0.30 per diluted share. 
Segment operating income was $180 million for the quarter, $153 million net of the special items, up significantly from the $11 million we reported for the quarter last year and driven by the margin gains Greg described earlier. Our manufacturing costs in the second quarter were $248 million, in line with the first quarter of this year.
We ended the second quarter with a cash balance of $191 million and had $713 million of availability on the revolving credit facility. Once again, we were undrawn on that facility during the quarter. At the end the quarter, our total debt-to-total capitalization ratio was 37%.
Year-to-date, cash is down over $200 million as CapEx, changes in working capital and interest payments outpaced EBITDA and tax refunds. As Greg mentioned earlier, we spent $140 million in capital expenditures during the quarter. This was up from the first quarter, primarily due to the full-plant turnaround at our Mandan refinery. Looking forward to the remainder of 2010, the only material turnaround work we have is currently underway at our Hawaii refinery.
Turning to the quarter, we see gasoline demand on the West Coast remaining stagnant, as California unemployment remains at its peak of around 12.5%, some 3% above the national average. Supply changes, however, are balancing low demand with crude runs, gasoline production and gasoline inventories all close to their five-year lows in July. As a result, so far in July, the West Coast crack is up more than $3 per barrel over July of last year, and the gasoline difference to the Gulf Coast is close to its five-year high for the month at over $0.25 per gallon. 
I'll close with providing guidance for the third quarter for your modeling purposes. In these assumptions, we have assumed the Anacortes refinery remains idle during the month of July and August, with a restart currently expected for September. We estimate throughput in thousands of barrels per day to be 75 to 85 in the Pacific Northwest, 55 to 65 in the Mid-Pacific, 110 to 120 in the Mid-Continent and 240 to 250 in the California region. 
OpEx guidance for the third quarter in dollars per barrel is as follows: 745 in the Pacific Northwest, 375 in the Mid-Pacific, 330 in the Mid-Continent and 710 in the California region. Our depreciation for refining is estimated at $95 million. An additional second quarter guidance items include corporate expense of $37 million, which includes the savings expected from recent changes to our corporate overhead structure and interest expense before interest income of $40 million. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Greg for closing comments. Greg?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: As I stated earlier, when we began this call, we are actually excited about the challenges and the opportunities. However, we also recognize that excess capacity in the refining industry will continue to put pressure on refining margins. Therefore, we are
componenttext:
As I stated earlier, when we began this call, we are actually excited about the challenges and the opportunities. However, we also recognize that excess capacity in the refining industry will continue to put pressure on refining margins. Therefore, we are very committed and focused to personnel and process safety efforts to drive continued improvement, our efforts to lower our cost structure, add value with aggressive non-capital and quick-hit capital programs and a very disciplined approach to cash management. 
Thank you for joining me on the call today. And with that, we'll now take questions.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

So what does that outlook [ph] look like on an annual run rate basis and when would we expect to have full benefit embedded in the numbers?

componenttext: On an annual basis, the corporate overhead charges, those will be fully implemented by 2011. componenttext: Yes, Doug, the guidance we gave on admin includes about $7 million of savings in the third quarter, and we expect a similar rate of savings in the fourth quarter. But as Greg said, we expect going into 2011, we'll be on track to see the full $40 million to $50 million.

componenttext: The balance, I guess the other $70 million to $90 million, that is non-cash, I'm assuming?

componenttextpreview: Generally, it is. It reflects a reduction in what we expected to have to do to increase our liabilities for post-retirement benefits and pensions prior to the changes we made, so mostly non-cash in the outer years, although there will be some cash savings
componenttext: Generally, it is. It reflects a reduction in what we expected to have to do to increase our liabilities for post-retirement benefits and pensions prior to the changes we made, so mostly non-cash in the outer years, although there will be some cash savings as time goes on, which Greg mentioned in the call. We started out small, maybe $5 million to $10 million in 2011 but growing to about $25 million, 10 years out.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, you thought, I guess, a little over a couple of months now, to look at the portfolio, and you made two, I think, slightly contradictory statements. One was that you think you got the right assets in the right places, but on the other hand, you're go
componenttext: Greg, you thought, I guess, a little over a couple of months now, to look at the portfolio, and you made two, I think, slightly contradictory statements. One was that you think you got the right assets in the right places, but on the other hand, you're going to carry a complete strategic review. Can you maybe just give a little bit of clarity as to what the message should be there? And if you could maybe speak to how Hawaii and Anacortes will fit within that review, that would be good enough though.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, regarding the question on the right assets in the right places, the markets that we operate in, we fundamentally like those markets for a variety of reasons. Regarding the look at the assets, really, we need to go back in and look at where we c
componenttext: Yes, Doug, regarding the question on the right assets in the right places, the markets that we operate in, we fundamentally like those markets for a variety of reasons. Regarding the look at the assets, really, we need to go back in and look at where we can drive improvements in the assets from a competitive standpoint and to really capture more value. So hopefully, it wasn't a contradiction as much as just a point that in general, we liked the Western part of the United States and those markets. However, we need to get the performance of certain assets up at a higher level. And so as you know, some of the assets are in niche markets, and so we intended just to further look at ways to capture more value, both on an individual basis and how we can integrate it in with our overall system.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: My final one is really just on the CapEx. Clearly, there's a limited amount of flexibility in terms of the environmental stuff you got to do, and of course, the acquisition of Wilmington required fairly substantial capital. I know you want to give hard nu
componenttext: My final one is really just on the CapEx. Clearly, there's a limited amount of flexibility in terms of the environmental stuff you got to do, and of course, the acquisition of Wilmington required fairly substantial capital. I know you want to give hard numbers right now, but just directionally, give us an idea of where you expect the flexibility to be on capital, on whether up or down, and 2010 would be a very good place to at least get us start to try to figure out what this means?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding the capital program, we cited a couple of examples in the talk that I just gave, particularly on the NOx programs and the improvements we're driving in benzene, better negotiations on some of the costs on that, too, for some of the projects that
componenttext: Regarding the capital program, we cited a couple of examples in the talk that I just gave, particularly on the NOx programs and the improvements we're driving in benzene, better negotiations on some of the costs on that, too, for some of the projects that we continue to look at those type of opportunities that we see a real focus on being able to drive improvements in our capital expenditures, and we see numbers coming in for next year in the same ballpark as 2010.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So $475 million to $500 million?
componenttext: So $475 million to $500 million?

componenttext: It's somewhere in the same general range. We haven't definitively got all of our plans there, but we're really working the numbers hard to make sure that we ensure the integrity of our assets but also manage, balance our cash as we go forward next year, so somewhere in that area.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up to Doug's question on the asset base, how're you viewing the Wilmington refinery? It looks like you had several operational hiccup. Do you have any thoughts on spending incremental capital there to improve reliability going forward?
componenttext: As a follow-up to Doug's question on the asset base, how're you viewing the Wilmington refinery? It looks like you had several operational hiccup. Do you have any thoughts on spending incremental capital there to improve reliability going forward?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, during the second quarter, we did have some operational hiccups, as you properly stated, at a Los Angeles refinery that created little bit of a lost profit opportunity for us. But if you take a step back and look at the overall programs, we've been m
componenttext: Yes, during the second quarter, we did have some operational hiccups, as you properly stated, at a Los Angeles refinery that created little bit of a lost profit opportunity for us. But if you take a step back and look at the overall programs, we've been making good progress since the refinery was acquired to really bring it up to our standards, to operate, to improve reliability, to improve the integrity of the assets, and we continue to focus on the programs where we get the greatest benefit from doing that. And so they have actually come up with some pretty innovative ways to help manage the required capital to get there, and at the same time, achieve the objectives of improving the overall assets. So it is probably one of our highest priority assets to really look at and be able to drive the improvements we need to, but also be very cognizant of the capital it takes to do that.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: Can you give us any specifics on those actions?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is Everett. Some of the things we do are a lot around the basic infrastructure in the refinery, and a lot of our capital around L.A. is improving that basic infrastructure. One example is the outage that we had in the quarter was driven by an e
componenttext: Doug, this is Everett. Some of the things we do are a lot around the basic infrastructure in the refinery, and a lot of our capital around L.A. is improving that basic infrastructure. One example is the outage that we had in the quarter was driven by an electrical outage. We have a cogeneration plant in the refinery, and we've got some money we're spending to improve the controls and the ability of that system to stay online when we have a disruption from the external electric supply. So it's primarily around infrastructure and making sure that, that infrastructure is consistent with our standards for reliability and safety in that refinery going forward.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one final question on Anacortes. You may have alluded to it, but can you discuss the business interruption insurance impact and how that's going to flow in here?
componenttext: And one final question on Anacortes. You may have alluded to it, but can you discuss the business interruption insurance impact and how that's going to flow in here?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a business interruption standpoint, I mean, as you're aware, we have insurance on both the assets and in our business interruption, and we are working through with the insurance companies on those claims right now. So we haven't put anything in our n
componenttext: From a business interruption standpoint, I mean, as you're aware, we have insurance on both the assets and in our business interruption, and we are working through with the insurance companies on those claims right now. So we haven't put anything in our numbers to get any payment back on the actual damage to the facilities once we collect on that claim. And on business interruption, we're working through that process with the insurers to be able to process the claim, which is, as you probably are aware, is either based upon 60 days or the $25 million. And we believe, based if you go back and look at the second quarter, you can kind of see what the results would've been if the facility would have been running and the results of that claim. So we're really working through with the insurance adjusters, and hope to get that resolved as we move through the second half of this year.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what's the regulatory risk on a September restart plan?
componenttext: And what's the regulatory risk on a September restart plan?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the most important thing for us is to basically go back and make sure the facility is absolutely in a position that we are comfortable restarting the plant. So we have intensive efforts going on, both through inspections, doing all of the rebuild wo
componenttext: Well, the most important thing for us is to basically go back and make sure the facility is absolutely in a position that we are comfortable restarting the plant. So we have intensive efforts going on, both through inspections, doing all of the rebuild work at the facility and working with the people at the facility. So we feel like we're on schedule and working very closely with all the necessary parties involved to restart the facility. So at this point in time, there's nothing that we're aware of that would preclude us from making that restart.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: Number one, just a follow-up on CapEx reduced again by $25 million. I mean, that is just to confirm that's reflecting maybe some change in your NOx or benzene compliance that you mentioned earlier, hence, it's a reduction and just not a deferral to the out-years of those costs?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, the actual reduction in the CapEx is by basically driving improvements in some of the things that we're working on, so where we found opportunities to lower the cost and still achieve what we set out to do, so it's specifically -- it's not a de
componenttext: Yes, Evan, the actual reduction in the CapEx is by basically driving improvements in some of the things that we're working on, so where we found opportunities to lower the cost and still achieve what we set out to do, so it's specifically -- it's not a deferral, as you said. But it is actually a reduction in things that we've been able to do. We have some areas in our marketing program where we reduced our capital expenditures lower than what we thought and achieved the same objectives. So it's really a combination of several small things that provide us a lower capital spend without deferring anything and without changing the scope of what we intended to do.

componenttext: In the benzene, I think we found improvements to drive across the whole system just reduce spending that it still achieves the same objectives. And the NOx, we talked about the NOx, around what was going around L.A. with the cogeneration in there.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010

componenttext: And the second follow-up is on the Anacortes update. I mean, I know last time we met in June, I believe you expected to hear in six to eight weeks maybe preliminary results from the government investigation. I mean, is that on track in conjunction with the restart? How will those two events relate to one another, if at all?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, Evan, the best we know is that sometime, probably by the latter part of August, we should hear from the Chemical Safety Board regarding their investigation of Anacortes. That's kind of a timeframe that we're aware of, and so that, i
componenttext: At this point in time, Evan, the best we know is that sometime, probably by the latter part of August, we should hear from the Chemical Safety Board regarding their investigation of Anacortes. That's kind of a timeframe that we're aware of, and so that, in conjunction with everything that we are going through to get the facility ready to restart, are progressing really as we planned.

Can you talk about if there's unusual items in the third quarter guidance, or just give us some color on those costs?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. I think throughput maybe the thing that's driving that on a per-barrel basis, a little higher. We've got that Hawaii turnaround. We've got Anacortes still down in July and August, coming up sometime in September. But beyond that, I don't know o
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. I think throughput maybe the thing that's driving that on a per-barrel basis, a little higher. We've got that Hawaii turnaround. We've got Anacortes still down in July and August, coming up sometime in September. But beyond that, I don't know of anything that we would expect to drive the absolute cost higher.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, your Mid-Continent refining assets are well positioned relative to growing supply in the region. Can you talk a little bit about what your expectations are for supply growth and infrastructure development and how they could influence crude disco
componenttext: Secondly, your Mid-Continent refining assets are well positioned relative to growing supply in the region. Can you talk a little bit about what your expectations are for supply growth and infrastructure development and how they could influence crude discounts in the Mid-Continent?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, in both of the refineries that you talked about, there are additional crudes coming to market over time that will have an impact on the business. And that's something that we look at all the time and determine how that availability of the c
componenttext: Well, I think, in both of the refineries that you talked about, there are additional crudes coming to market over time that will have an impact on the business. And that's something that we look at all the time and determine how that availability of the crude, the impact of the differentials, the ones that we enjoy today, how they will be impacted in the future as we go forward. So in the short term, we don't see any immediate impact, although we are gaining some advantages by some crude that we can supply to the Salt Lake City refinery. But longer term, that's part of our strategic review to determine how we position ourselves as additional crude comes to the market and the impact it will have on the differentials for the supply to those refineries.

componenttext: No, in the second quarter, when our Mandan refinery was down for a major turnaround, as we talked about, but the crude discounts weren't anything out of the unusual there, so...

componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know we have the answer to that question right now, Paul. I mean, we're not doing anything out of the normal as it relates our hedging activities. Everett, do you have any additional insight?
componenttext: Well, I don't know we have the answer to that question right now, Paul. I mean, we're not doing anything out of the normal as it relates our hedging activities. Everett, do you have any additional insight?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Paul. On some of the longer-haul crudes that we use and some of the other crudes we have in storage, we, of course, hedge those crudes. So when we have a fall and flat price, we have some gains on the hedging side, which you'd expect with the offsets
componenttext: No, Paul. On some of the longer-haul crudes that we use and some of the other crudes we have in storage, we, of course, hedge those crudes. So when we have a fall and flat price, we have some gains on the hedging side, which you'd expect with the offsets on the physical side. What happens in the fourth quarter depends on what happens to the flat pricing and how much crude we have on the longer-haul side at that point in time. So I don't usually look at that as an unusual variation.

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question is that as of -- why now, do you have any outstanding hedges existed for the third quarter?
componenttext: I guess, my question is that as of -- why now, do you have any outstanding hedges existed for the third quarter?

headline: Tesoro Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know specifically offhand, but I suspect that there are a few since we don't clear our crude or clear our storage at the end of each quarter. There's usually some bridging across from one quarter to another, so it wouldn't surprise me if there wer
componenttext: I don't know specifically offhand, but I suspect that there are a few since we don't clear our crude or clear our storage at the end of each quarter. There's usually some bridging across from one quarter to another, so it wouldn't surprise me if there were. But those hedges would again be tied to the physical crude that's in storage and would just represent an offsetting move to the physical.
